New fiction by Robert Coover: “Over the years, we got used to thinking of Marleen as something eerie but mostly harmless at the edge of our lives.”
Sasha Frere-Jones on D’Angelo’s new album. “Black Messiah” is an unexpected masterpiece, at the right time.
In a new book, Steven Brill argues that health care needed major surgery but got a Band-Aid instead. Malcolm Gladwell reviews “America’s Bitter Pill.”
Reviews of “A Map of Betrayal,” “Indigo,” “The Marquis,” and “Severed.”
J. C. Chandor has done something startling: he has made an anti-“Godfather.” David Denby on a more morally nuanced mobster film.
David Remnick on the N.Y.P.D., Bill de Blasio, and reading James Baldwin’s “Fifth Avenue, Uptown” in today’s New York.
Elizabeth Kolbert drops by Renzo Piano’s new office in Rome, where he has recently been appointed “a senator for life.”
Jiayang Fan plays basketball with the chef whose memoir, “Fresh Off the Boat,” has been adapted into a new sitcom on ABC.
Michael Schulman hangs out with music students as they try on recital-worthy ballgowns.
James Surowiecki on America’s housing addiction: the social beneﬁts of the government’s mortgage subsidies are questionable, but the costs are plain.
McGill makes his début as a soloist with the orchestra in Carl Nielsen’s Clarinet Concerto. Alan Gilbert conducts.
Joan Acocella on the “Air Mail Dances.”
Russell Platt surveys the diversity of indie opera.
Hannah Goldfield on a superlative seasonal seafood menu.
Sarah Larson drinks at the new Rainbow Room.
Andrew Marantz profiles Emerson Spartz, a digital-media guru profiting from the cat photos, catchy headlines, and GIFs that fill your Facebook feed.
David Sedaris on a family trip to the beach: “It’s not that our father waited till this late in the game to win our hearts. It’s that he’s succeeding.”
After nearly a century, a town at the center of the Armenian genocide tries to make amends. Raffi Khatchadourian reports from his grandfather’s home town.
Shouts & Murmurs by Cora Frazier. “Attention, patrons: For the remainder of the performance of ‘Cora’s Life,’ the role of Cora will be played by Sting.”
New fiction by Colin Barrett: “Off school, and drinking when she liked: Pell had Nick under her thumb.”
Louis Menand on the paperback revolution that transformed publishing: did it transform culture, too?
Elaine Blair on the novelist Rachel Cusk, who finds fiction too fake. Is autobiography the answer?
Reviews of “The Lives of Others,” “The End of Days,” “The Republic of Imagination,” and “Bohemians, Bootleggers, Flappers, and Swells.”
Alex Ross on Meredith Monk and Gabriel Kahane, members of an exploding category of composer-vocalists.
Emily Nussbaum on the British series “Black Mirror,” which offers up a dystopian critique of life lived through a screen.
Peter Schjeldahl on a new show at MOMA: “The Forever Now: Contemporary Painting in an Atemporal World” captures an art form in crisis.
Anthony Lane on the sharply suspenseful new film by the Dardenne brothers, starring Marion Cotillard, and on a new movie set in the Russian outback.
Marriage equality has been slow to come to the Deep South—but, Amy Davidson writes, a court case in Mississippi may change that.
It turns out that seven minutes, as a unit of time, has elemental and panacean properties. Nick Paumgarten explains.
Tad Friend tours Williamsburg’s Bayside Fuel Oil Depot with J. C. Chandor, whose new movie captures New York at its nadir.
Larissa MacFarquhar talks vodka tampons, water-based lubricants, and green M&Ms at a sex-ed conference.
Emma Allen visits the San Francisco test kitchen where cookie disruption has been taken to a new level.
A spare adaptation of Sondheim, at the Laura Pels.
Amelia Lester eats at an Argentine steak house on the Lower East Side.
A new material may transform computers, cell phones, and cancer treatments—if we can just figure out how to use it. John Colapinto reports.
Colum McCann on his father’s writing shed, which “always smelled damp inside, as if the rain rose up out of the carpet.”
Peter Schjeldahl on Rachel Harrison. She is the least digestible contemporary artist, but may also be the most important.
Rebecca Solnit on unpredictability in Native American creation myths.
Researchers get closer to outwitting a killer.
Yiyun Li on growing up in Beijing in the eighties: “I did not yet know that some people were assigned a fate that left them on the sidelines, listening.”

article_name: In the Land of the Possible
summary_text: She has President Obama’s ear. To what end?
Teju Cole on his favorite film, Krzysztof Kieślowski’s “Red,” and how it influenced his novel “Open City.”
Steve Schapiro’s rarely-seen photographs of the historic march.
Conservationists hope that a bloody campaign to exterminate invasive mammals will forestall an ecological crisis. Elizabeth Kolbert reports.
Surgery, Brezhnev, and a wintry bus ride: Tatyana Tolstaya recalls how her writing life began.
Shouts & Murmurs by Ethan Kuperberg: “Deck the halls of our mountain hideout, / Fa la la la la, la la la la! / Hope all humans have not died out…”
New fiction by Nuruddin Farah: “He wishes he were an artist and Ahmed a nude subject, posing to be drawn.”
Sasha Frere-Jones on the new album: the group has the curiosity of Radiohead, but there is no “puffed-up rejection of being a live rock band.”
Hilton Als reviews the Broadway revival. Cooper “is all pathos” as a brilliant misfit.
“Adam Gopnik on John Merriman’s “Massacre.” A new history tells the hour-by-hour story of the 1871 Commune’s rise and fall.
Reviews of “A Brief History of Seven Killings,” “Arctic Summer,” “Stalin,” and “Paper Love.”
David Denby on David Oyelowo’s meditative, barbed Martin Luther King, Jr., in Ava DuVernay’s new film.
The C.I.A. report explains how cruelty became policy, Jane Mayer writes, but now that torture has become politicized, it may be hard to stop.
"Hunger Games" and "Harry Potter" fans stood with fast-food workers demanding a higher minimum wage. Reeves Wiedeman reports.
Michael Schulman talks with the Monty Python founding member, who will perform the oratorio “Not the Messiah (He’s a Very Naughty Boy)” at Carnegie Hall.
Alastair Bruce, who advises the cast of “Downton Abbey” on protocol, discusses the visiting Cambridges with Rebecca Mead.
James Surowiecki explains why cheap oil is probably too good to last.

article_name: Skrillex and Diplo Ring in the New Year
summary_text: The E.D.M. stars team up.
Hilton Als assesses the influence of Lily Tomlin and Ruth Draper on the comic.
Russell Platt on the “Byzantine Holiday Pop-Up,” “All Is Calm,” and other seasonal music.
Hannah Goldfield eats at a restaurant serving pan-African cuisine, in Harlem.
Emma Allen drinks and plays trivia at a Greenpoint bar.
If Elizabeth Holmes succeeds, getting a blood test could become a lot easier for patients. Ken Auletta reports.
Ben McGrath on the Montreal defenseman who unnerves his opponents with ebullience: “They hate it when he smiles on the ice,” Subban’s mother says.
The entertainment industry seeks the future in viral video. Tad Friend reports.
A meteorologist lives alone at an isolated Arctic outpost, measuring the temperatures, the snowfall, and the winds. Photographs by Evgenia Arbugaeva.

article_name: Uber Reviews for Charon, Boatman of Hades
summary_text: Shouts & Murmurs by Cirocco Dunlap: “Love that in addition to ancient drachmas and babies’ blood he now takes Chase QuickPay!”
New fiction by Elizabeth McKenzie. “Mama?” I called, even though of course she was no longer living. Instead, a large beast swept in.
Hurricane Mama, at Walt Disney Concert Hall, is almost as loud as a jet engine. Alex Ross on the new popularity of organ music.
Joan Acocella on the history of hoarding, from Grey Gardens to the DSM-V.
Reviews of “There Once Lived a Mother Who Loved Her Children, Until They Moved Back In,” “There Must Be Some Mistake,” “Napoleon,” and “The Lost Tribe of Coney Island.”
Watching “The Affair” is like listening to a couple bickering about where to eat. Emily Nussbaum on the new Showtime series.
Anthony Lane on Paul Thomas Anderson’s Pynchon adaptation: at times, you want him to leave the writer’s orbit and follow his own strange star.
Amy Davidson on what Eric Garner’s death reveals. Crime in New York peaked in 1990—and yet the police still treat ordinary citizens as criminals.
In 1994, a thirteen-year-old with a plastic toy gun was shot and killed by an NYPD housing officer. Mark Singer looks back.
Russell Brand read from his version of “The Pied Piper,” in which the rodents form “an anarcho-egalitarian rat collective.” Michael Schulman reports.
Sarah Larson talks to the actor Michael K. Williams, of “The Wire”: he’s now the A.C.L.U.’s new ambassador for ending mass incarceration.
Lauren Collins on marginalia, which is to Oxford as a cappella is to Princeton: it has enthusiasts numbering in the thousands.
After a ninety-one-million-dollar renovation, the museum includes a “immersion room” in which you can project your own wallpaper designs.
Joan Acocella on a “Live from Lincoln Center” broadcast of the School of American Ballet’s fiftieth Workshop performance.
Sasha Frere-Jones on two bands reviving the city’s rock scene.
Richard Brody on a highlight from Film Forum’s noir series “Chandler, Hammett, Woolrich & Cain.”
Shauna Lyon eats food from Uttar Pradesh on the Upper West Side.
Sarah Larson drinks at a pub with a history in the Edison Hotel.
Robin Wright reports from Gaziantep, the Turkish city that has become America's gateway to the Middle East’s most complicated war in a hundred years.
Too much polish, too much kitsch: Adam Gopnik on how shopping, tourism, and luxury are changing Paris.
Burkhard Bilger on three eight-year-old boys training for the Youth Bull Riders World Finals.
D. T. Max profiles Hans Ulrich Obrist, of London’s Serpentine Gallery. He “seems less to stand atop the art world than to race around, up, over, and through it.”
Shouts & Murmurs by Paul Rudnick. “The Threeway: In which a mom and her two grown daughters secretly discuss divorcing their husbands, until orgasm.”
New fiction by Tim Parks: “He was always ready to be meeting people. To be saving their souls.”
Sasha Frere-Jones on the new album: it’s a bit defanged, but every m.c. is as strong as he was twenty years ago.
James Wood on Samantha Harvey’s “Dear Thief”: “It is a strange and exhilarating journey, unlike anything I have recently encountered.”
Reviews of “Elsa Schiaparelli,” “Leningrad,” “Shark,” and “The Hilltop.”
Emily Nussbaum reviews one of TV’s few truly experimental series.
Dan Chiasson on Olena Kalytiak Davis, whose new book, “The Poem She Didn’t Write and Other Poems,” is at once tawdry and oddly pure.
David Denby on two films about independence: “Wild,” starring Reese Witherspoon, and “Mr. Turner,” with Timothy Spall.
Jelani Cobb on the “grim recognition” spurred by Ferguson: African-Americans are hemmed in between the dangers of crime and the perils of policing.
Dana Goodyear attends a party for a new social app. Shouldn’t say which one, but it starts with a “W” and rhymes with “hisper.”
Emma Allen and the “O.C.” star discuss adulthood over a tuna melt.
Bob Marley’s son Rohan is starting Marley Natural, a marijuana company. Andrew Marantz reports.
James Surowiecki on why consumers, not the Supreme Court, could undermine the Affordable Care Act.
Les Freres Corbusier creates a Herbert Hoover-themed musical spectacular.
David Denby on highlights of a complete Robert Altman retrospective.
Russell Platt on the concert, which features the Either/Or ensemble, conducted by Richard Carrick.
Sasha Frere-Jones on the cool kids who refuse to act cooler than you, at Town Hall on Dec. 3 and 4.
Emma Allen attempts to recreate the travels of Lewis and Clark in state-themed drinks, at a new bar in Williamsburg.
Amelia Lester eats particularly fine Korean fried chicken.
The theft of Justice Felix Frankfurter’s papers changed the history of the Supreme Court.
Joseph Mitchell, a great chronicler of city life, on his boyhood in North Carolina, in this second chapter of his previously unpublished memoir.
George Packer profiles the most powerful woman in the world.
How a stranger’s feces might save your life. Emily Eakin reports.
Shouts & Murmurs by Ian Frazier: “Hard by a wide and radiant roadway I saw a bright sign...and the seven and the eleven were upon the sign.”
New fiction by Etgar Keret: “All I want is a single bud, even a joint, to smoke with a pretty girl who laughs at my jokes.“
Nicholas Lemann searches for the real secrets to Google’s success. The tech giant thinks it’s changing corporate management forever, but so did G.M.
Reviews of “Wagstaff,” “Chaucer’s Tale,” “Let Me Be Frank with You,” and “The Moor’s Account.”
Hilton Als on the chilly union of Glenn Close and John Lithgow, in a revival of “A Delicate Balance.”
Swedish influence is everywhere in pop music—even Taylor Swift’s new album. Sasha Frere-Jones on the rise of Swedepop.
Anthony Lane on a new film about Alan Turing, starring Benedict Cumberbatch and Keira Knightley. It is “the opposite of enigmatic.”
Alex Ross on the dynamic young conductor: He “ascends the podium looking like an overgrown boy who has been given an orchestra for his birthday.”
David Remnick on what Havel can teach us: at times of crisis, “as Havel’s example made plain, despair is surrender and unforgivable.”
Nick Paumgarten on the M.M.A. fighter, Marine, and son of Gordon Lish, who returned from China to write “Preparation for the Next Life.”
Elisha Almonte, sixteen, went to Washington to accept an award from Michelle Obama. Sarah Larson rode along.
The retired basketball star Yao Ming was in town for the première of his documentary, and visited the Central Park Zoo with Reeves Wiedeman.
Sixty moms from all over signed up for “Speed Dating for Mom Friends,” at the Bell House. Rachel Levin tagged along.
Killer Mike and El-P, at Stage 48.
What to do in New York during the festive season.
Sasha Frere-Jones writes that Sleaford Mods “is the musical equivalent of a hard, unfiltered spotlight: look at us and listen.”
Andrea K. Scott writes about Judith Scott’s magnificent fibre-wrapped sculptures in “Bound and Unbound.”
Jiayang Fan sips the future—in the form of modernist cocktails—on the Upper East Side.
Hannah Goldfield writes that there’s never been a better time to eat Chinese in New York, or a worse time to eat at Shun Lee, a Lincoln Center standby.

article_name: The Wide Stars Above Our Sky

summary_text: The world is being rebuilt in code. Now there’s an agency to help top programmers get superstar salaries. Lizzie Widdicombe reports.
Does Daniel Ek’s streaming service represent salvation for the music industry or the blueprint for its decline?
It’s already being used to manufacture human tissue; could a whole organ be next? Jerome Groopman reports.
Ben McGrath profiles Scarlett, StarCraft’s most compelling player.
Steve Coll reports from Pakistan on what “surgical strikes” leave behind.
Shouts & Murmurs by Megan Amram. “Version 2.5 Sabbath upgrade: Saturday to Sunday. Saturdays now available for work, heterosexual intercourse.”
New fiction by Brad Watson: “What he had done to bring down his father’s wrath no one knew.”
David Denby on Jon Stewart’s directorial début, starring Gael García Bernal, and Amir Bar-Lev’s documentary about the Penn State sex-abuse scandal.
Michael Specter on a new biography of the Russian scientist. “Pavlov’s lab was essentially a physiology factory, and the dogs were his machines.”
Reviews of “How to Build a Girl,” “Hold the Dark,” “The Unsubstantial Air,” and “On Immunity.”
James Wood on Hermione Lee’s new biography: it tells the story of a great talent “buried under a heavy plinth, and discovered only just in time.”
The Republicans figured out how to win the midterms; now they need to show that they can govern. George Packer on their strategy leading up to 2016.
In Brooklyn, Loretta Lynch’s nomination for Attorney General was a victory for the home team. Jeffrey Toobin talks to a federal judge.
New York City’s ginkgo trees will each drop their leaves in a single night. Oliver Sacks explains.
Damian Kulash, the band’s lead singer, plans to turn its music into genetic code. Andrew Marantz explains.
John Lahr visits a retrospective for the Public Theatre’s poster designer, in whose hands the posters themselves became an event.
Until tech companies learn to accept the cultural disruption that comes with diversity, James Surowiecki argues, they won’t close the gender gap.
The band performs from its new album, “El Pintor.”
Peter Schjeldahl on a show celebrating “perhaps the oddest American artist of the last half-century.”
Alex Ross on a composer who “has mapped a world that never quite existed in the history of the arts.”
Amelia Lester eats at a new Californian restaurant on Park Avenue South.
Sarah Larson on a new midtown spot opened by Le Bernardin’s longtime wine director.

article_name: By the Waters of the Llobregat

summary_text: She isn’t the only Democrat who may run for President in 2016. Is another Clinton Presidency inevitable?
Amid an atmosphere of increasing intolerance, Israel’s conservative President calls for civility—and pays a price. David Remnick reports.
Shonelle Jackson may become the first American to be executed despite a jury’s unanimous vote for life. Paige Williams reports from Alabama.
Allen Kurzweil spent forty years searching for his boarding-school bully. He got more than he bargained for.
Shouts & Murmurs by Yoni Brenner: The player with the lowest score will also receive a postdoc in semiotics, but from the Timberwolves.

article_name: The Alaska of Giants and Gods
summary_text: New fiction by Dave Eggers: “The Lower Forty-eight was full of cowards and thieves and it was time for mountains and people of truth and courage.”
Adam Gopnik on a new biography by Richard Zoglin that will make even Hope-haters curious about his good early work.
Reviews of “The Book of Strange New Things,” “The Children Act,” “Limonov,” and “Village of Secrets.”
Emily Nussbaum on the return of HBO’s cult comedy starring Lisa Kudrow. The second season is as spiny and audacious as the original.
After “Moneyball,” Bennett Miller offers a doomier sports story. Anthony Lane reviews “Foxcatcher,” with Steve Carell, Channing Tatum, and Mark Ruffalo.
Steve Coll on Obama’s options after the midterms: he could still close Guantánamo and reform immigration, even without Congressional Republicans.
Nick Paumgarten climbs One World Trade Center with Ueli Steck, the daredevil Swiss mountaineer. “Pretty boring route,” Steck said, of the stairs.
AOL pays Shingy a six-figure salary for “watching the future take shape across the vast online landscape.” Andrew Marantz reports.
Michael Schulman followed Short, who has just published a memoir titled “I Must Say," as he visited "S.N.L." on a victory lap.
The guys behind Sir Kensington’s ketchup have curated “Fries of New York,” a pop-up exhibit on the Bowery. Mark Singer visits.
“With his heartbreakingly emotive baritone, Jorge has reinvigorated samba and other Brazilian genres.” Beginning November 10th.
Andrea K. Scott highlights “The Forever Now,” at MOMA, and “On Kawara–Silence.”
Richard Brody highlights “Inherent Vice,” “Annie,” “Into the Woods,” and more.
“If Ron Burgundy were real, he would bring his lady friends to this new Tribeca restaurant,” writes Shauna Lyon.
John Donohue on Deer Tick, Michael Arenella’s Winter Ball, and Sleater-Kinney’s reunion at Terminal 5.
The Civilians consider pornography from the perspective of its makers in “Pretty Filthy”—and other highlights of the season chosen by Shauna Lyon.
Russell Platt highlights Joyce DiDonato’s performances at the Met and Zankel Hall, among others.
Indian dance at the Temple of Dendur, and contemporary flamenco at City Center.
Alec Wilkinson on the National Magazine Award-winning Modern Farmer. Ann Marie Gardner, its editor, calls it “a farming magazine for media professionals.”

section_name: Onward and Upward with the Arts
summary_text: “I don’t do anything until it shows up, and when it shows up I’m a playwright.” Butterworth talks to Emma Brockes about “The River,” with Hugh Jackman.
Rachel Aviv on a Hasidic sex-abuse scandal. After a child-molestation case, leaders of the community turned against the whistleblower, Sam Kellner.
Chris Rock doesn’t think of himself as unusually funny. “I’m not the funniest person I know,” he says. “I’m not the tenth-funniest person I know.”

article_name: To the Cockroach in My Apartment
summary_text: Shouts & Murmurs by Courtney Gaughan Bowman: “I’ll eat the food I buy; you eat the cardboard under the sink.”
New fiction by Antonya Nelson: “Maybe all mothers existed in order to torment their daughters with news of the future.”
There’s no doubting Christopher Nolan’s craft, but his new movie is fervently incomprehensible. David Denby reviews “Interstellar.”
There was a time when the first step in any move against the Soviets might begin with an invitation to cocktails.
Reviews of “Us,” “The Dog,” “How to Be a Victorian,” and “Back Channel to Cuba.”
Athletic performance is freakishly high. Manufacturing quality is off the charts. Now for the bad news. James Surowiecki on the improvability era.
Hilton Als reviews a revival of “The Real Thing,” starring Ewan McGregor, Cynthia Nixon, Maggie Gyllenhaal, and Josh Hamilton as an adulterous foursome.
Sasha Frere-Jones on William Basinski. With “The Disintegration Loops” and “Cascade,” he has built a career from fragments of old audio tape.
When is Ebola seen as a gift? Apparently, when you are a candidate for the Senate. Margaret Talbot on midterm anxiety.
Dan Gilroy explains to Tad Friend how Weegee, the crime photographer, inspired his new film, “Nightcrawler.”
Ian Parker samples “un-American” confections with Wayne Thiebaud, who’s renowned for his paintings of cakes and pies.
The QueensWay, a proposed linear park, would be more than twice as long as the High Line. Ian Frazier walks part of the route.
Mark Singer hangs out near the courthouse with the “Doonesbury” cartoonist, who has just wrapped Season 2 of “Alpha House.”
Isango Ensemble’s production, starring Pauline Malefane, opens this week.
Some of the director’s best films were made for German television, including “Fear of Fear,” and “The Stationmaster’s Wife,” at Lincoln Center.
Celebrating a new album, “Don’t Cross Myrtle,” at the McKittrick Hotel, in Chelsea.
Emma Allen drinks in Bushwick: “The vibe was a cozier version of the living space your roommate turned into a kombucha-fermenting zone.”
Hannah Goldfield eats “convincing country food” at a new restaurant in the East Village inspired by trips to Newfoundland and the Bayou.
Once upon a time, food was about where you came from. Now it’s about self-expression. John Lanchester on how foodism has gotten out of hand.
Adam Gopnik on our age of mutated pastry. What can account for the phenomenon of the Cronut and its crowds?
The food on cruise ships is now so important to most passengers that new ships are often designed around eating opportunities.
Millions of people have sworn off wheat, but there’s little science to support them. Michael Specter investigates.
Dana Goodyear on Anya Fernald, a food entrepreneur, whose company, Belcampo, offers a delicious—but pricey—alternative to industrial food.
Rivka Galchen recalls her diet as a medical student: “Even the basically ﬁne cafeterias were mysteriously terrible.”
Will Mackin remembers M.R.E.s in Iraq: “There’s something wrong about ‘Pork Rib’ in the Sunni triangle.”
Chang-rae Lee on his memories of cafeteria fare at boarding school: “The food was not good. But, then, it wasn’t meant to be good.”
Jaime Joyce on banned foods in prison: “Whole fruit (potential projectiles), meat on the bone (potential shivs), corn on the cob (potential moonshine).”
Shouts & Murmurs by Jazmine Hughes: “I just think you deserve an evening eating Popeyes in your underwear. Do you want my HBO GO password?”
New fiction by Jess Row. “Some people, you get a little liquor in them and it’s all about the old times. They want to huddle up and sing Lady Gaga.”
Alex Ross reviews John Adams’s controversial “The Death of Klinghoffer”: the score shudders with grief, powerfully answering Adams’s critics.
Hilton Als on the playwright and director. The challenge in writing “Straight White Men” was to find a way to be both herself and not herself.
Reviews of “The Invisible History of the Human Race,” “The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace,” “Some Luck,” and “This Blue.”
Sasha Frere-Jones on the new Dylan box set: it captures the moment when, following a 1966 motorcycle crash, he became a different musician.
Emily Nussbaum on HBO’s soaring, inventive new miniseries, starring Frances McDormand. It casts a West Coast spell on scenes of Yankee repression.
Anthony Lane on Dan Gilroy’s new film, starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Rene Russo. “Nightcrawler” is dangerously beautiful, primed to grip and entrap.
Amy Davidson looks back on the Berlin Wall, which came down twenty-five-years ago this month—and which, it’s often said, “fell by mistake.”
Slow food, slow money, now slow cars—the New York minute will henceforth be sixty seconds long. Nick Paumgarten reports.
Reeves Wiedeman meets the South Korean merchandise manager and baseball fan who has become the Kansas City Royals’ good-luck charm.
Quincy Jones and the twenty-eight-year-old blind piano player dropped in on a jam session at a musicians’ union in Hell’s Kitchen. Tad Friend listened in.
James Surowiecki on the advantages of business breakups. Spin-offs and divestitures, unlike mergers, have a pretty strong track record.
The couple performs songs from their newly released début album, a stunning collection of eloquent duets.
Shauna Lyon visits a new deep-dish establishment in SoHo.
Jiayang Fan on Drunken Munkey, an Upper East Side Old Bombay-themed café.
Sarah Larson on the Public Theatre’s bar.
Amelia Lester visits the iconic original location, in Tribeca.

article_name: The Many Faces of Tracee Chimo
summary_text: Michael Schulman on the actress’s diverse roles, including in “Orange Is the New Black,” “Lips Together, Teeth Apart,” and “The Heidi Chronicles.”

article_name: How I Didn’t Get Myself to a Nunnery

summary_text: His influence on the federal judiciary is complex: symbolically rich but substantively hazy.
Kelefa Sanneh on the pro-life version of EMILY’s List, whose sole aim is to abolish abortion.
As the epidemic widens, the virus is mutating. Geneticists are racing to keep up. Richard Preston reports.
Nick Paumgarten profiles Joel, who tells him, “You know, if you type ‘Billy Joel’s house’ into Google maps, you get Madison Square Garden.”
Shouts & Murmurs by Cora Frazier: “And here, comrades, is Ms. Valery Jackson, who I see paid her Verizon bill with her Bloomingdale’s card.”
Fiction by Tom Hanks: “We took hundreds of selﬁes with the Earth in the window.”
David Denby on the new David Ayer movie, starring Brad Pitt, and Volker Schlöndorff’s film about the last night of occupied Paris.
Dan Chiasson reviews the National Book Award-nominated poem about race in America: “It is an especially vital book for this moment in time.”
Reviews of “Blackballed,” “Blood Aces,” “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage,” and “The Story of Land and Sea.”
Alex Ross calls Peter Sellars’s staging of Bach’s masterwork, with the Berlin Philharmonic and the Rundfunkchor, “one illumination after another.”
Peter Schjeldahl on Leonard Lauder’s promised gift of works by Picasso, Braque, Gris, and Léger: It “isn’t so much a show as an institutional organ transplant.”
Jelani Cobb on why our government doesn't look like the people it’s supposed to represent.
Reeves Wiedeman rides along with Ariel Pink, who is indie rock’s most hated man of the moment.
Rebecca Mead joined Bell Hooks and Laverne Cox, of “Orange Is the New Black,” for a conversation about life, butts, and ice cream sundaes.
Twenty-five former Miss Subways winners ate salmon with Megan Fairchild, of the musical “On the Town,” and Michael Schulman, at Ellen’s Stardust Diner.
Sophie Brickman attends a competition, at Columbia, led by Dr. W. Ian Lipkin, to develop low-cost technology-driven solutions to the Ebola epidemic.

article_name: A new play by Suzan-Lori Parks
summary_text: Sterling K. Brown stars as a slave who fights in the Confederate Army in order to gain his freedom.
Alex Ross previews the Miller Theatre’s “Composer Portrait” concert, with the International Contemporary Ensemble.
Richard Brody highlights “Bert Williams: 100 Years in Post Production,” as well as “The Cave of the Silken Web” and “The Iron Mask.”
Emma Allen visits Charlie Palmer’s new bar in the lobby of the Lipstick Building, which features sagging bow ties and high muck-a-muckery.
Amelia Lester on Central European comfort food in Bay Ridge, where a meal might wind up as three courses of perfectly fried dough, in various guises.
Why are so many animals now in places where they shouldn’t be?

section_name: Onward and Upward with the Arts
summary_text: Alex Ross reviews five recent biographies and one novel, and asks: “How did Beethoven become ‘BEETHOVEN’?”
George Packer profiles the filmmaker, whose new documentary, “Citizenfour,” tells the inside story of the N.S.A. whistle-blower.
Jon Lee Anderson reports from the Central African Republic on one priest’s mission to save the people an international intervention could not.
Shouts & Murmurs by Paul Rudnick: “I have also volunteered as a tutor, helping public-school children learn to lie about it.”
Fiction by Kirstin Valdez Quade: Last night, Crystal dreamed she was sitting naked on the church’s rectory couch.
Why have copyright protections grown and grown? Louis Menand on what the intellectual-property battles really mean.
James Wood on the Australian writer who withdrew her novel “In Certain Circles” from publication, in 1971. It’s now available, and it’s brilliant.
Dan Chiasson on “Faithful and Virtuous Night”: Rarely has the idea of old age as a second childhood been developed with such eeriness and poignancy.
New fall books, including “The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher,” “Nora Webster,” and “Love Me Back.”
Hilton Als on a revival of Terrence McNally’s play, which offers a tinsel-and-barbed-wire view of stardom.
Peter Schjeldahl on “Matisse: The Cut-Outs,” a new show at MOMA that “will give you as much aesthetic pleasure as you can stand and then some.”
Alex Ross on the Russian soprano at the Met: she hit treacherous high notes but rarely gave chills.
Anthony Lane on Alejandro González Iñárritu’s new film, in which Michael Keaton stars as a washed-up movie superhero.
“This epidemic won’t be over soon,” Michael Specter writes, “but that is even more reason to focus on what works.”
Kelefa Sanneh dropped in on the boxers Manny Pacquiao and Chris Algieri, who kept things civil over an Italian supper while promoting an upcoming fight.
Over biryanis, Tom Stoppard and Rosemary Harris compared their upbringings in colonial India, where “India Ink” is set. Ian Parker listened in.
Emma Allen visited the sushi restaurant for bigwigs that Larry Gagosian and Masayoshi Takayama have opened beneath a Madison Avenue art gallery.
James Surowiecki on the company’s evolution from online DVD rental to streaming video and original content.
Today, every chic woman has a little black dress. But, until Coco Chanel helped to revolutionize fashion, in the Jazz Age, a lady in black was often in mourning.
Peter Schjeldahl on the Brooklyn Museum’s survey of recent art from the borough.
Sarah Larson visits a bar in the East Village inspired by the horror writer H. P. Lovecraft.
Amelia Lester eats at a new bistro in the Ludlow Hotel from the Torrisi team.
Russell Platt on an Israeli harpist.
Hilton Als previews “Employee of the Year,” part of the “Crossing the Line” festival.
Lawrence Lessig wants to reform campaign finance. All he needs is fifty billionaires.
Lauren Hilgers on employment agencies that can get Chinese immigrants kitchen jobs across the country in a few hours.
How a doctor, a trader, and a billionaire got entangled in a vast financial fraud.
As Sayyid Ahmed collects trash in Peter Hessler’s Cairo neighborhood, he reveals the contradictions of life in modern Egypt.
So Ted says, “Will you marry me?” And, before I can respond, the Soviet scientists come out from behind this rock.
Fiction by Haruki Murakami: “Each time they had sex, she told Habara a strange and gripping story afterward.”
Emily Nussbaum on “the smartest drama currently on the air.”
Jeffrey Frank reviews a new biography. In “On His Own Terms,” Richard Norton Smith has written what will probably stand as a definitive Life.
Reviews of “Geek Sublime,” “Infidel Kings and Unholy Warriors,” ”Barracuda,” and “The Last Kings of Sark.”
Evgeny Morozov on how the ideas behind Project Cybersyn, a futuristic experiment in cybernetics from nineteen-seventies Chile, still shapes technology.
Peter Schjeldahl on the works of the sculptor and installation artist which “radiate a quality that is as rare in life as it is in art: character.”
David Denby reviews Jason Reitman’s new film, a survey of contemporary alienation, and Michael Cuesta’s new thriller about the journalist Gary Webb.
Evan Osnos on the protests in Hong Kong. How will an increasingly authoritarian state handle a new generation of young activists?
Reeves Wiedeman on Dan Bongino, an N.Y.P.D. officer turned Secret Service agent turned Republican candidate for Congress.
Jiayang Fan hangs out with the hosts of a Chinese-language radio show aimed at students, as they debate how to cover the Hong Kong protest.
Tad Friend and William H. Macy talk about “Rudderless,” Macy’s directorial début, and go ukelele shopping.
James Surowiecki on a smart climate trade: Norway will give Liberia millions of dollars in aid, and Liberia will work to slow its deforestation.
Sasha Frere-Jones writes that the L.A.-based band “found its natural sound by letting itself dissolve.”
Hilton Als on the artistic director of the SoHo Rep.
Andrea Scott writes that a conceptual artist strikes gold at the Kitchen.
Joan Acocella on Jane Moss’s founding of the White Light Festival.
Jiayang Fan visits a speakeasy-style social club in Harlem.
Amelia Lester visits a food court filled with buzzed-about venders.

article_name: I Was Reading Up on My Hellenic Math

summary_text: Jennifer Gonnerman on Kalief Browder, a Bronx teen-ager who was accused of stealing a backpack. He spent over a thousand days awaiting trial.
Masha Gessen on the writer’s dissenting voice. As Russia has grown more politically repressive, Ulitskaya’s fiction “has moved in for a confrontation.”
The Kentucky senator wants to go mainstream with the libertarian ideology he shares with father, Ron Paul. Can it win him the Presidency?
His painting of the Virgin Mary caused a brouhaha at the Brooklyn Museum; since then, he has gone right on producing startlingly original work.
Shouts and Murmurs by Calvin Trillin: I read something on the Internet. A friend of mine read the same thing, which makes me think it’s true.
Fiction by Kevin Canty: “The world divided itself into the drinking and the hangover, day and night, and we lived for the nights.”
Anthony Lane reviews “Gone Girl,” “The Two Faces of January,” and “The Blue Room.”
Joan Acocella on Robinson’s unflinching new novel, which returns to Gilead, Iowa. She has written “a character that people say novelists can’t create.”
Reviews of “My Grandfather’s Gallery,” “Yeah! Yeah! Yeah!,” “The Symmetry Teacher,” and “The Walk Home.”
Hilton Als reviews a stage adaptation of Ingmar Bergman’s 1973 film: van Hove “conveys intimacy and convention as both life force and death.”
Sasha Frere-Jones reviews Aphex Twin’s new album, which may be his most accessible and joyful. It’s “a landscape in which humans are welcome.”
For too long, Margaret Talbot argues, a misplaced idea of privacy “stood in the way of treating an assault on an intimate partner as a crime.”
Ben Greenman on Tim Fite, whose latest album is a satirical meditation on the encroachment of technology into modern life.
John Seabrook on Chuck Leavell, the Rolling Stones’ main keyboardist, who is also an honorary forest ranger and a tree advocate.
Emma Allen and the painter Eric Fischl get in a fender bender at Art Southampton, where he’s been stealthily photographing fairgoers.
Rebecca Mead takes in Three Day Hangover’s production of “Macbeth,” at a Midtown bar.
The South African singer appears in a recital at Carnegie Hall’s “UBUNTU,” a celebration of South African music and arts.
Richard Brody reviews “The Princess of France,” “Li’l Quinquin,” and “Heaven Knows What.”
Russell Platt previews a new staging by Peter Sellars, with Simon Rattle conducting the Berlin Philharmonic.
Hannah Goldfield eats Southern barbecue on the Red Hook waterfront.
Emma Allen visits a bar and barber opposite Tompkins Square Park.

article_name: Poem for the Opening of the Hamilton Fish Park Pool, 1936
The World We Should Have Stayed In

summary_text: Why Europe’s highest court ruled that the right to privacy trumps the Internet. Jeffrey Toobin reports.
“Only a very small percentage of women genuinely feel that motherhood isn’t for them. Was I really that exceptional?”
The U.S. wants the Kurds to do two potentially incompatible things: fight ISIS and resist seceding from Iraq. Dexter Filkins reports.
Leon Botstein has built the college in his own polymath image; can it outlast him?
Photographs, by Matt Black, of California’s punishing drought, with commentary by Dana Goodyear.
Shouts & Murmurs by Ian Frazier: “Look at the larger picture. Anheuser-Busch is our moral beacon shining in the fog, and it is also the fog.”
“One night they had a contest to see who could write the most frightening story. . . .” Fiction by Paul La Farge.
James Wood reviews a “blazingly original” début novel by Eimear McBride.
Joyce Carol Oates reviews Amis’s new Holocaust novel, set in Auschwitz.
Reviews of “Soldier Girls,” “The Zhivago Affair,” “The Narrow Road to the Deep North,” and “The Paying Guests.”
Emily Nussbaum on Netflix’s new “tasty crime thriller,” and Jill Soloway’s indie-inflected Amazon series starring Jeffrey Tambor.
David Denby reviews a brilliantly entertaining new film, starring Bill Nighy, and John Curran’s Outback drama, featuring Mia Wasikowska and Adam Driver.
Ben McGrath on brain injuries, Ray Rice, and why it’s getting harder to ignore the N.F.L.’s “culture of sanctioned violence.”
Anthony Lane on the Irish actress who is soon to perform at BAM. “Some who’ve tried to learn it have gone mad,” she said.
Ian Frazier on the photographer who knows New York City’s whales personally.
David Owen on Alfred Portale, a New York chef developing meals for Singapore Airlines. Among the challenges he faces: turbulence.
“I like them if they have coffee stains and look used,” the Irish rock-and-roll singer told Alec Wilkinson, at Good Records, in the East Village.
The fastest-rising choreographer in contemporary dance débuts two highly-anticipated programs at New York Live Arts this month.
Michael Schulman on Bridget Everett, who says that her onstage persona is “a crazy maniac who doesn’t get laid enough, so I have to put my sexual energy somewhere.”

article_name: Joan Acocella on Wendy Whelan's Farewell
summary_text: Joan Acocella on a ballerina’s farewell: “Whelan, though she is forty-seven, doesn’t pretend she’s ready to stop dancing.”
Dan Kaufman on a guitarist with deep Andalusian roots who performances weekly at the Spanish Benevolent Society, in Manhattan.
Sarah Larson visits Bibi, a candlelit East Village wine bar that “feels like an outpost of safety and comfort.”
Shauna Lyon on a restaurant for well-moneyed vegans and their friends.
Nick Paumgarten on the rise of the GoPro camera: “Its charm lies perhaps in its sublimated conveyance of self, its sneaky tolerable narcissism.”
Rivka Galchen profiles Misty Copeland, ballet’s rising star, whose goal “is to become the first African-American principal dancer with A.B.T.”
Feminism, free love, and a superhero's real powers.
Lizzie Widdicombe on a new wave of designers and bloggers that is changing the fashion world.
“Our XX-B Annihilator Halftrack Urban Ambassador is out of fuel and nobody can find the gas cap.” Shouts & Murmurs by Bruce McCall
Fiction by Victor Lodato: “Soon, he knew, the freak would come, the soul-suck, if he didn’t get one of two things: more crystal or a sound sleep.”
Sasha Frere-Jones reviews Perfume Genius’s expansive, exuberant new album, which is “outside most conceptions of pop.”
Adam Gopnik on “The Crack-Up,” the modern confessional, and the lives of Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald.
Reviews of “Eichmann Before Jerusalem,” “The Teacher Wars,” “Whiskey Tango Foxtrot,” and “Panic in a Suitcase.”
Hilton Als on Kenneth Lonergan’s play: “It reminds us of who we once were and who we are.”
Peter Schjeldahl on color-field painting, a movement born between Abstract Expressionism and Pop.
Anthony Lane on Terry Gilliam’s institutional chaos and Nick Cave’s gothic gloom.
What separates a war from a “counterterrorism campaign”? Amy Davidson on the semantics of the latest American action in Iraq and Syria.
Ben McGrath meets Dick Conant, who’s spent months canoeing the Hudson: he “isn’t an outdoorsman so much as a nomad.”
Tad Friend visits the set of “This Is Where I Leave You,” a home that had to fulfill certain unusual requirements.
Raffi Khatchadourian and Rachel Sussman hunt for New York City’s oldest living things.
James Surowiecki on Utah’s cost-effective approach to chronic homelessness: instead of putting people into shelters or halfway houses, just hand them the keys to a new place.
Alex Ross writes that Jonny Greenwood’s score of Paul Thomas Anderson’s “There Will Be Blood” is “among the strongest creative alliances in contemporary Hollywood.”
Hilton Als on Blythe Danner in Donald Margulies’s “The Country House” and James Earl Jones in Kaufman & Hart’s “You Can’t Take It with You.”
Sasha Frere-Jones on how to bake a song.
Emma Allen visits a new bar at the former General Theological Seminary, in Chelsea.
Hannah Goldfield visits a restaurant inside an Urban Outfitters “retail concept.”
Bill Cosby was America's ideal dad, but his actual life was more complicated. Kelefa Sanneh on what Cosby would and wouldn't say onstage.
Jerome Groopman on an experimental cancer drug that can transform malignant cells into healthier ones.
“Pacino sometimes asks himself, ‘When am I just gonna sit back and smell the golf balls?,’ “ John Lahr writes. “The answer is not soon.”
Fast-food workers aren't just kids earning gas money. Many are raising families, and often McJobs are the only jobs available.
A back-to-school drawing by Roz Chast.
The Lady of Accomplishment is able to eat a full Meal without dribbling curry on herself.
Fiction by Danielle McLaughlin: “It was dizzying: the unimaginable expanses of space and time, the vast, spinning universe.”
Alex Ross on the influence of Walter Benjamin and Theodor Adorno, who had “one of the twentieth century’s richest intellectual conversations.”
Reviews of “The Magician’s Land,” “Cutting Teeth,” “Bulletproof Vest,” and “The Roman Guide to Slave Management.”
Emily Nussbaum on a crass teen-mortality series, with Zoe Levin and Octavia Spencer, and a lively and emotionally satisfying fantasy series, on Starz.
David Denby on a “crackling” prison drama and a “hollow, high-minded folly” with James McAvoy and Jessica Chastain.
David Remnick on Obama’s foreign-policy vision: “It is a mistake to dismiss caution as weakness.”
Nick Paumgarten on Konstantin Petrov, an electrician at Windows on the World whose photos offer a portrait of the Twin Towers.
John Seabrook and Paul Williams, the president of ASCAP, visited St. Nicholas Music Inc., publisher of “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.”
Max Nichols, the son of director Mike Nichols (“The Graduate”), has directed his own film, “Two Night Stand,” starring Analeigh Tipton and Miles Teller.
Sarah Larson dropped by a Brooklyn practice room where the new-music ensemble Two Sides Sounding were rehearsing an opera scene called “Stop and Frisk.”
As befits the birthplace of opera, Italy sets its movies to music with a particular verve, nowhere more than in the work of Federico Fellini,…
Richard Brody on the Taiwanese director’s enduring achievements and artistic frustrations.
In Catherine Gund’s documentary “Born to Fly,” which opens on Wednesday, at Film Forum, the choreographer Elizabeth Streb says that when she went to college…
In 1642, when a small, scraggly hook of land east of Manhattan was awarded to a reform minister, or dominie, in Dutch, it became known…
Amelia Lester writes that two new restaurants downtown make a convincing argument for a coherent Antipodean cuisine.

John McPhee on the era of Dick Kazmaier and his own experience as an unofficial Princeton football mascot: “Aged eight, I was promoted to a position on the field. Every fall day after soccer, I went down the street to university football practice and hung around my father, the trainers, the coaches, the team.”
“Mauritanian slaves are not restrained by chains: slavery is in large measure an economic and a psychological institution.” Alexis Okeowo reports.
Anonymous has targeted Middle Eastern dictators, the Church of Scientology, PayPal, and the Ferguson police. Does it do more harm than good? David Kushner reports.
“The silent sniper fire of overdoses from pills and heroin has hit Staten Island harder than anyplace else in the city.” Ian Frazier reports.
I love to hear from my readers. Why don’t you text me? Sexts are also totally welcome, any time of day.
Fiction by Thomas McGuane: “He should have spent the day at Jorgensen’s with his arm up a cow’s ass.... But the roll of money in Ray’s pack made him wonder how anxious he was to get back to work.”
James Wood on David Mitchell’s sprawling new novel: “Mitchell has plenty to tell, but does he have much to say?”
Reviews of “In the Kingdom of Ice,” “The Embrace of Unreason,” “Mr. Tall,” and “The Bend of the World.”
Alex Ross on the pleasures and frustrations of Spotify: “There are legitimate questions about the aesthetics and ethics of streaming.”

“The saddest thing about ‘If I Stay’ is that it affords Moretz so little opportunity to be non-sad.” Anthony Lane reviews the movie version of the best-selling book, with Chloë Grace Moretz and Jamie Blackley, and “The Last of Robin Hood,” with Dakota Fanning, Kevin Kline, and Susan Sarandon.
Steve Coll on Obama’s options: in Iraq they’re terrible, in Syria, they’re even worse.
Roger Angell on Derek Jeter’s final season with the Yankees: His “ease, his daily joy in his work, has lightened the sadness of his farewell.”
Sarah Larson talks to the fedora-wearing Belle and Sebastian founder about “God Help the Girl,” his new film musical.
Reeves Wiedeman and Brad Gilbert take their seats among the tennis fans to watch Serena Williams and Roger Federer practice.
Michael Schulman visited J&M Special Effects, where pyrotechnicians were demonstrating the fireworks for “You Can't Take It With You.”
A revival of the Terrence McNally satire, with Nathan Lane, Matthew Broderick, Stockard Channing, and Megan Mullally.
Richard Brody’s highlights, including a Mankiewicz retrospective, MOMA’s “To Preserve and Project,” and “Retro Metro,” at BAM.
John Donohue’s highlights, including Hozier, “Twenty Years of Freedom,” at Carnegie Hall, and Def Jam.
Andrea K. Scott’s highlights, including “Henry Matisse: The Cut-Outs,” at MOMA, as well as a Robert Gober survey and the Met’s “Assyria to Iberia at the Dawn of the Classical Age.”
Russell Platt’s highlights, including the finale of Alan Gilbert’s Nielsen Project and Schubert’s “Winterreise,” with short animated films by William Kentridge, at Alice Tully Hall.
Katia Bachko’s highlights, including Ira Glass’s variety show, “Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Host,” as well as a Pina Bausch evening-length work, “Kontakhof,” at BAM.
Shauna Lyon’s highlights, including “Scenes from a Marriage,” directed by Ivo van Hove, and Young Jean Lee’s “Straight White Men,” at the Public.
Shauna Lyon on a new Flatiron district restaurant from the chef David Waltuck.

Emma Allen writes that “the garden, once thronged with lovelies sporting crop tops and even a few Polish denizens of the neighborhood’s Old Guard, has been shut down.” What’s next for the struggling Greenpoint bar?
Anxieties at age eight: appendicitis, typhoid, kidnapping, milk.
The Cambridge classicist Mary Beard has become a feminist heroine for her fight against misogyny online.
How Cassandro became the drag-queen star of lucha libre.
Gaza is divisive. Young Jews are questioning Israel. Connie Bruck reports on a powerful lobby trying to keep its influence.
Last night, Pa went out to buy some kale leaves from a darty-eyed man on a street corner. His high-priced purchase turned out to be a ziplock baggy full of chard.
Fiction by Joseph O’Neill. “There are a lot of ethical, pleasant, and dependable people notionally out there. It’s intimidating, frankly.”
Nathan Heller on William Deresiewicz’s “Excellent Sheep,” which, in attempting to debunk one myth of higher education falls prey to another.
Reviews of “In the Wolf’s Mouth,” “The Rise and Fall of Great Powers,” “The Removers,” and “Tambora.”
Adam Gopnik on the history, pleasures, and perils of bipedalism. “Why people walk is a hard question that looks easy.”

David Denby reviews Michael Winterbottom’s new film. Coogan and Brydon’s tough assignment is to eat, drive, write high-toned culinary drivel, and one-up each other with riotous impressions of movie stars.
Ferguson is sixty-seven per cent black, but fifty of its fifty-three police officers are white. Jelani Cobb on disenfranchisement, disillusionment, and the protests in Ferguson.
Reeves Wiedeman visits a workshop hosted by Peoples’ Justice, a police accountability group, on the best practices for capturing police encounters on camera.
Tad Friend on Scott Campbell, a tattoo artist who began inking bikers and moved on to Heath Ledger and Courtney Love, and who recently co-created a line of wines called Saved.
Kelefa Sanneh on Suburbia, the Bushwick apartment where ten friends host concerts intended to re-create the suburban punk paradise of their youth.
Ian Frazier dropped by Smokey Bear’s seventieth birthday celebrations in Alley Pond Park, in Queens, where Smokey appeared to be in fine form.
Women performers are on the rise in the electronic-dance-music scene.
John Donohue previews Paul Thorne’s upcoming appearance at City Winery, where Thorne will play anthemic songs from his tenth album, “Too Blessed to be Stressed.”
Hilton Als on the extraordinary Tavi Gevinson, and her star turn in “This Is Our Youth,” now at the Cort Theatre on Broadway.

“Nonesuch Records at BAM: Celebrating a Label Without Labels” will likely be “a historic event,” writes Russell Platt. The series, which kicks off the Next Wave Festival, features Steve Reich, Philip Glass, the Kronos Quartet, and Laurie Anderson.
“The aggressively relaxed dress code and clubhouse-like atmosphere take nothing away from the sophisticated northern-European food,” Amelia Lester writes, of the new restaurant in Tribeca.
Does the Constitution protect corruption?
After doctors refused to treat a seventeen-year-old boy, he returned with a knife and stabbed the first doctor he saw. Christopher Beam reports on a health-care system in crisis.

In the eighties, an animal-rights activist fell in love with Bob Robinson and had his child. Years later, she learned that Bob Robinson was Bob Lambert, and Bob Lambert was a spy. Lauren Collins reports.
Michael Specter on Vandana Shiva, an activist who accuses biotechnology companies such as Monsanto of imposing “food totalitarianism.” Others believe that G.M.O.s are the key to solving world hunger.

The most dazzlingly free-associative verbal comedian of his time was also an acrobatic master of slapstick and an actor whose range spanned whiz-bang antics and criminal menace, domestic charm and aching tenderness.
A group called SKITTISH, the Society of Kindhearted Individuals Terriﬁed of Trauma, Icky Stuﬀ, and Heartache, has issued a manifesto calling for extreme trigger warnings.
Fiction by Tessa Hadley. “She couldn’t get rid of the terrible knowledge that Dom had brought; it seemed to be stuck inside her, in her stomach or her throat.”
James Wood on James Kelman, whose funny, sour vernacular experiments with Lowland Scots and Glaswegian dialect push and twist the language, sometimes to breaking points.
Reviews of “The Invention of News,” “Some Desperate Glory,” “The Vacationers,” and “Flying Shoes.”
Alex Ross on the L.A. Philharmonic’s performances at the Hollywood Bowl: “You have the sense, on the best nights, that it has been released back into the wild.”
Sasha Frere-Jones on new music out of Nashville. Eric Church and Luke Bryan prove that almost every genre can fit in a country song.
Michael Fassbender performs in a great painted papier-mâché head, and John Lithgow and Alfred Molina play a couple in need of a home.
George Packer on ISIS: “It’s hard to believe that the ambitions of ISIS will remain confined to the boundaries of the Tigris and Euphrates.”
After Robin Williams ended his singularly pyrotechnic life last week, his friend Penny Marshall’s phone kept ringing. All the old gang—Carol Kane, Julie Kavner, Robert…

Nick Paumgarten on Christian Rudder, a co-founder of OkCupid, who has written a book called “Dataclysm: Who We Are (When We Think No One’s Looking),” and who wants you to know that the Internet is one giant experiment, and we’re all its subjects.
Elizabeth Kolbert on the posse of fossil enthusiasts who are digging away at Beecher’s Trilobite Bed, the site of some of the most coveted finds in the history of paleontology.
James Surowiecki on the economics of Ebola drug development. The lack of a treatment is disturbing but predictable. What will persuade pharmaceutical companies to develop unprofitable drugs?
The tenth-anniversary celebration includes D’Angelo,the headliner, as well as Alice Smith, Fishbone, Valerie June, and Shabazz Palaces (pictured).
Hilton Als previews “Bootycandy,” Robert O’Hara’s new play. “The punch line in O’Hara’s work? His recognition and dissection of that ill-fitting straitjacket called political correctness.”

Andrea K. Scott visits an exhibition at the New Museum of artists from the Middle East, North Africa, and their diasporas. “The last major exhibition in New York to touch on similar themes was a milquetoast affair,” but “no one will lob that accusation” at this show, Scott writes.
Sarah Larson visits a midtown saloon opened by a former P.J. Clarke’s bartender.

Hannah Goldfield visits Union Square’s new restaurant. “The food, though not particularly adventurous, is much better and fresher than you might expect from a restaurant in one of Manhattan’s most trafficked hubs.”

article_name: The Lost Art of Letter Writing

summary_text: Mobsters climbed by way of crime. Why don't black criminals get the same deal? Malcolm Gladwell on Alice Goffman’s “On the Run: Fugitive Lift in an American City.”
Claudia Roth Pierpont on how the struggle for civil rights shaped Nina Simone’s life and career, and on a controversial new movie, “Nina,” starring Zoe Saldana.
Russia's President sees himself as the leader of a new anti-Western, conservative axis, and his actions in Ukraine have made him a hero at home. David Remnick reports.
Shigeru Ban has designed inexpensive homes for disaster victims and penthouses for the one per cent in Manhattan. Now he’s designing a new art museum in Aspen, Colorado.
Metro-North's Hush Plus initiative introduces the Almost Quiet Car, the Insanely Loud Car, and more.
Would you rather have a Picasso or be Picasso? Fiction by César Aira.
A history of the nineteen-seventies chronicles the fall of the American consensus and the rise of the right.
Reviews of “The Most Dangerous Book,” “Sylvia, Queen of the Headhunters,” “The Mad and the Bad,” and “Time Present and Time Past.”
Hilton Als on Stephen Adly Guirgis. His plays offer poetic portraits of ex-cons, addicts, and losers; they also reveal the influence of standup on contemporary American theatre.
Emily Nussbaum reviews “The Knick": "It's proof that even an ambitious director can't overcome a blinkered script."
Do people enjoy him because he’s funny or because he’s not that funny? Sasha Frere-Jones on "Mandatory Fun," Weird Al's new album.
It has taken a long time for Hollywood to recognize what Brown accomplished. David Denby reviews a new bio-pic starring Chadwick Boseman and produced by Mick Jagger and Brian Grazer.
Margaret Talbot on how viral videos, like the ones of Ray Rice and Eric Garner, “turn us all into ersatz judges and jurors."
Richard Preston on the Ebola outbreak, and on Daniel Bausch, an American doctor who is working in an Ebola ward in Kenema, Sierra Leone.
Emma Allen on Tadashi Yanai, the richest person in Japan, who recently swung by the Uniqlo Fifth Avenue flagship store for the launch of SPRZ NY, an arty clothing line.
Mark Singer on Roger Angell, who travelled to the National Baseball Hall of Fame to receive the J. G. Taylor Spink Award “for meritorious contributions to baseball writing.”
James Surowiecki on Fox’s bid for Time Warner. Imperial mergers make for good drama, but are they good business?
THERE’S MORE TO the recovering Rockaways than the beach. A sprawling art festival, co-hosted by the Rockaway Artists Alliance, the National Park Service, and MOMA…
Hilton Als on the Sydney Theatre Company's revival of Jean Genet's "The Maids" at the Lincoln Center Festival, starring Isabelle Huppert and Cate Blanchett as Jean Genet's murderous sisters.
Franz Schubert, Alex Ross writes, "is, in several ways, the most unfathomable of the great composers." Bard's summer music festival explores Schubert's wondrous music and his mysterious life.
David Denby looks at two movies in which dinner parties go awry, both by Luis Buñuel and playing at BAM. "Eating is the central ritual of haut-bourgeois civilization, and he aims for the gut."
Sarah Larson visits Minus5 Ice Bar in the midtown Hilton.
In Tables for Two, Amelia Lester calls the modest but lovely dinner service at Iris Café Store #9 the best-kept secret in Brooklyn Heights.

Michelle Goldberg on the dispute over what it means to be a woman. The transgender-rights movement has forced a rethinking of what sex and gender mean, and radical feminists now find themselves shunned as reactionaries on the wrong side of a sexual-rights issue.
John Lanchester decodes the language of the finance industry: When it comes to discussing money, “incomprehension is a form of consent.”
Did the Chicago police coerce witnesses into pinpointing the wrong man for homicide—allowing a serial killer to commit more murders? Nicholas Schmidle tells the tragic story of Tyrone Hood.
Alec Wilkinson on the poet Edward Hirsch, who confronts the loss of his son in a book-length elegy, “Gabriel.”
Shouts & Murmurs by Marc Philippe Eskenazi: A glossary of terms for unathletic kids attending baseball camp.

Fiction by Paul Theroux: “It all stank pleasantly of wickedness, and if I’d known anything I would have recognized it as sensual. But I was ﬁfteen, small for my age, soon to enter my sophomore year of high school. Away from my house I wasn’t sure who I was; I had no self, nothing to put forward, no idea that I dared express, no voice, nothing but the bravado I’d learned from Eddie.”
Pankaj Mishra reviews Elizabeth Pisani’s “Indonesia Etc.,” an exuberant and wise guide to one of the world’s most diverse countries.
Reviews of “An Untamed State,” “The Ballad of a Small Player,” “Secrecy,” and “The Road to Emmaus.”
Emily Nussbaum reviews “The Strain,” a new horror series on FX, and “The Leftovers," which captures the disorientation of grief in a way that is rare for television.
Peter Schjeldahl on the Christopher Williams retrospective, at MOMA: it “brings a tonic chill to an art summer enfevered by the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney.”
Anthony Lane on Brendan Gleeson’s new movie, “Calvary,” which plunges us into the guts of a moral crisis, and “A Master Builder,” based on the Henrik Ibsen play.
In Israel and Palestine, the politics are as disheartening as the casualties are heartbreaking.
Three guys decided they should build a floating pool that would neutralize the current and filter contaminants.
For Ansel Elkins, who did a writer’s residency at the Standard East Village, breakfast and coffee were complimentary; lunch, dinner, and alcohol were not.
R. J. Cutler spent decades making documentaries about the wily likes of Bill Clinton and Dick Cheney. A burly man with a red beard and…
James Surowiecki on companies that have social responsibility written into their charters.
Julia Stiles stars in Scott Organ’s “Phoenix,” at the Cherry Lane.
Wilco’s lead guitarist explores his avant-garde roots in a weeklong residency at the Stone.
Boston Lyric Opera presents a “fringe” version of Jack Beeson’s “Lizzie Borden” at Tanglewood.
“The sandwiches are cheap, the ocean views free”: Shauna Lyon explores the food scene at Rockaway Beach.
“You guys are going to think I’m drunk,” Gil (Owen Wilson) says, in Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris,” explaining that he’s been transported, via Peugeot,…
The First World War preoccupied Hollywood directors even while the war was still being fought. Richard Brody on the Museum of Modern Art’s series “The Great War.”
Elizabeth Kolbert on how the paleo diet got trendy—and its environmental costs.

section_name: Onward and Upward with the Arts
summary_text: The Carpenter siblings are breaking into the rare-violin trade, selling centuries-old Strads to hedge-fund types. Rebecca Mead investigates.
